Construct CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 support with relative CeO2-ZrO2-rich surface by peptization method to tame the thermal stability of Pd species in three-way catalysts Wei Wang Conceptualization Methodology Software Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft a Yi Zhao Software Formal analysis a Xinyi Yin Investigation a Linmei Wang Formal analysis a Jun Fan Investigation a Shanshan Li Conceptualization Methodology Project administration Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Jianli Wang Conceptualization Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Yaoqiang Chen Conceptualization Project administration a b a Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology Ministry of Education College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China aKey Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China b Institute of New Energy and Low-Carbon Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China Institute of New Energy and Low-Carbon Technology Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China bInstitute of New Energy and Low-Carbon Technology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The sintering of Pd under high temperature operation conditions usually leads to serious deactivation of Pd-based TWCs. As the stronger Pd-CeO2-ZrO2(Pd-CZ) interaction in the form of Pd-O-Ce bond favors to anchor Pd species than that of Pd-Al2O3, to construct a CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) support with a relative CZ-rich surface is beneficial to selectively enlarger the Pd-CZ interface to maintain the excellent catalytic function of Pd/CZA TWCs. For the purpose, a facile one step peptizing method has been put forward to achieve the CZA material to stabilize Pd species. By XRD, TEM and Mapping, it could be inferred that comparing with the conventional precipitation method and peptization-precipitation method, the CZ nanoparticles could be homogeneously distributed on the network structure of porous Al2O3 by in-situ growth in the peptization method. Then the CZA with a relative CZ-rich surface could be obtained, which interacted strongly with the supported Pd species and thus stabilized the Pd species in oxidation states and smaller particle size. As a result, the Pd/CZA catalyst from peptization method exhibited the best activity for CO, NO, C3H6 and C3H8, the T90 (complete conversion temperature at 90% conversion) of which was reduced by 40 °C, 50 °C, 40 °C and 20 °C comparing with that of Pd/CZA derived from conventional precipitation method even being thermal aged at 900 ℃/3 h, respectively. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CZA materials CZ-rich surface Peptization method Precipitation method Pd-only three-way catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Three-way catalysts (TWCs), aim at eliminating hydrocarbons (HCs), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon monoxide (CO) simultaneously, is an effective technology for gasoline exhaust treatment [1]. Pd-based TWCs have attracted much attention due to their relatively low cost and excellent low-temperature oxidation capacity of CO and HC [2,3]. However, the serious deactivation of Pd-based TWCs caused by thermal sintering of Pd under high temperature operating conditions (occasionally>1000 ℃) is a significant challenge for its widespread application. [4,5]. To weaken the deactivation induced by Pd sintering, there are three main strategies. One is to confine noble metal nanoparticles (NMs) in microenvironments, such as being encapsulated in a porous matrix shell [6,7]. Taking Wu's work as an example [6], they introduced CeO2 into the outer layer of Pd to form a core-shell structure, which not only protect the Pd particle from aggregating during reaction processes, but also inhibit the Pd species from being leaching. The second is tuning the microenvironment of metals by intruding promoters [8,9]. For example, Du et al. [9] suggested the addition of Ba can stabilize Pd species. After adding Ba, the average Pd nanoparticles diameter in catalyst can be reduced from 8.1 nm to 4.3 nm. The third is to regulate the metal-support interactions. As the two typical supports in Pd-based TWCs, massive literatures have reported to inhibit the sintering of Pd species by optimizing the characteristics of CeO2-ZrO2(CZ) and Al2O3, including surface element distribution, crystal size, phase structure and morphologies [10–12]. For example, Dai et al. [13]. tamed the stability of ultrafine Pd active phases (<3 nm) by an NA-Al2O3 architecture with cross-linked γ-Al2O3 nanosheets in flowerlike morphologies as a support. Deng et al. [14]. constructed the CZ with partial κ-Ce2Zr2O8 phase to strengthened Pd-CZ interaction to generate highly reactive Pdδ+ (δ ≥ 3) and immobilize palladium nanoparticles. In addition, the different Pd-support interaction strength between Pd-CZ and Pd-Al2O3 has also been manifested, which leads to distinct thermal stability of Pd species. In detail, the Pd-CZ interaction in the form of Pd-O-Ce bond plays a prominent effect in anchoring Pd and therefore inhibiting the sintering of Pd nanoparticles [15]. Simultaneously, the transfer of electrons from Pd to CZ at the Pd-CZ interface is also favorable to the oxidation of HC and CO [16]. However, as for the interaction between Pd and Al2O3, it will significantly reduce at high exhaust gas temperatures due to the phase transformation of Al2O3. As a result, the specific surface area of the material will greatly decrease and the PdO species may be reduced to metallic Pd0, which would weaken the oxidation reaction of CO and HC [17]. Nowadays, the CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) material, which not only combines the oxygen storage capacity of CZ and high specific surface area of Al2O3, but also exhibits superior thermal stability in inhibiting the sintering of both CZ and Al2O3 nanoparticles due to the well-known “barrier effect”, has been regarded as a promising support for Pd-based TWCs considering the increasingly stringent emission regulations [18,19]. Then considering the distinct strength of Pd-support interaction, it is one of the most critical technological challenges to selectively enlarge the Pd-CZ interface instead of Pd-Al2O3 between the different support components when trying to maintain excellent catalytic function of CZA supported Pd-only TWCs. For the purpose discussed above, the CZA material with a relatively CZ-rich structure has been designed and constructed by researchers through conventional impregnation method [20]. However, the inhomogeneous element distribution of CZA materials prepared by conventional impregnation method usually leads to undesirable thermal sintering of CZ nanoparticles and pore collapse. Then, some modified methods, such as co-precipitation method [21], deposition-precipitation method [22] and sol-gel method [23] have been put forward. While the preparation period of the above methods is relatively long, and abundant toxic organic reagents are used as solvents during sol-gel synthesis, which limit their industrial production and application [24,25]. In this work, a facile one step peptizing method, in which the CZ nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed on the network structure of porous Al2O3 by in-situ growth, has been put forward to achieve the CZA material with a relative CZ-rich surface for the advanced Pd-based TWC. For comparison, two other CZA samples were achieved by using conventional precipitation method and peptization-precipitation method, respectively. Besides, the relationship between the properties of CZA materials prepared by different methods and the activity of their supported Pd-only three-way catalysts were also studied. Experimental preparation of CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 materials Chemicals including 64.85 g Ce(NO3)3∙6H2O (CP), 20.78 g pseudo-boehmite (CP) and 1.86 g La(NO3)3∙6H2O (CP) were purchased from Chengdu Kelong Chemical Reagents Factory (Chengdu, China). The 55.98 g ZrOCO3 (CP) was purchased from YiXing Xinxing Zirconium Company Limited (JiangSu, China). Other chemicals including 1.91 g Ba(NO3)2 (AR), 1 mL HNO3 (AR), 560 mL NH3∙H2O (AR) and 720 g (NH4)2CO3 (AR) were purchased form Chengdu Lucheng Chemical Reagents Factory (Chengdu, China). The composition of three CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3-La2O3-BaO (CZA) samples is same, namely, CeO2: ZrO2: Al2O3: La2O3: BaO = 29 wt%: 21 wt%: 43.5 wt%: 2.5 wt%: 4 wt% (nCe/nZr = 1/1), which were marked as CZAx (x = 1, 2, 3). CZA1 was synthesized by the precipitation method. First, the mixed Ce-Zr solution was achieved by dissolving Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O and ZrOCO3 with distilled water and nitric acid, respectively. Then, the quantitative pseudo-boehmite, La(NO3)3·6H2O and Ba(NO3)2 was dispersed by distilled water as the substrate, the mixed CZ solution was precipitated by the buffer solution (NH3·H2O: (NH4)2CO3 = 1: 1) at pH=8.8 onto it. Next, the obtained precipitate suspension was hydrothermal aging at 90 °C for 6 h. Finally, the precipitates were filtered, washed and dried. CZA2 was synthesized by the peptization-precipitation method. First, the quantitative pseudo-boehmite, La(NO3)3·6H2O, Ba(NO3)2 and nitric acid was added to ball milling tank and milled for 30 min to peptize. After that, it was washed and dispersed by distilled water as the substrate, then the Ce-Zr was precipitated and treated in the same way as CZA1. CZA3 was synthesized by the peptization method. First, the quantitative pseudo-boehmite, La(NO3)3·6H2O, Ba(NO3)2 and nitric acid was added to ball milling tank and milled for 30 min to peptize. Afterwards, the Ce-Zr mixed solution was introduced into ball mill tank and continues to be ball milled for 30 min. After that, the precipitates were filtered, washed and dried. The above materials were calcined in air at 1000 °C for 4 h, and the obtained materials were marked as CZAx (x = 1, 2, 3). Preparation of Pd-only three-way catalysts The 1 wt% Pd-only TWCs with CZAx materials as supports were synthesized by impregnating Pd(NO3)2. After dried and thermally calcined at 550 °C for 3 h, the fresh catalysts were acquired (marked as Pd/CZAx-f). Then, the powders coated to cylindrical cordierite monoliths (Corning, USA, 400 cells/in.2 and 2.5 cm3) with the desirable loading of 160 g·L − 1. Afterward, the fresh catalysts were further thermal aged at 900 °C for 3 h to obtain the corresponding aged catalysts (marked as Pd/CZAx-a). Evaluation of the three-way catalytic activity The three-way catalytic activity of Pd/CZA catalysts were evaluated in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. The composition of simulated exhaust gasses were CO (5100 ppm), O2 (4390 ppm), NO (1100 ppm), C3H6 (220 ppm), C3H8 (110 ppm), H2 (110 ppm), H2O (10%), CO2 (9.3%) and N2 (as balance gas), and the space velocity was fixed at 50,000 h − 1. The catalysts were treated under the simulated exhaust at 550 °C for 1 h before test. Then the conversions of all pollutants under the condition of continuous temperature rise were detected by the Thermo Scientific AntarisIGS Gas Analyzer. Characterization techniques The morphology and size distribution of samples were characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (FEI Talos F200x, Thermo Scientific, USA), in which the accelerating voltage is 200 kV. The surface properties of samples were tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on an electron spectrometer (XSAM-800, Kratos, British) with an Al Ka X-ray source. All profiles were calibrated with C1s (284.6 eV) as the standard. The structures properties of samples were measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns on a diffractometer (Rigaku D/MAX, Rigaku Corporation, Japan) with a Cu-Kα radiation, whose detection range was from 10 ° to 90 ° and step size is 0.02° The texture properties of samples were performed at −196 ℃ by N2 adsorption-desorption isothermals on a Quantachrome automated surface area & pore size analyzer (Autosorb SI, Quantachrome, USA). Before test, sample was pretreated in He flow at 300 ℃ for 3 h to clean the surface. The redox properties of samples were tested by Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on a thermal conductivity detector (TP-5076, Xianquan Co. Ltd, China). First, sample was pretreated in He flow at 450 ℃ for 40 min. After cooling down to RT (room temperature), gas flow was changed to 5 vol% H2/N2 flow and reduction signals with temperature were recorded from RT to 900 °C with a heat rate of 10 °C/min. The Pd dispersion was calculated by the CO-chemisorption method. First, sample was treated at 450 °C for 1 h in H2 flow before measurement. After cooling to −78 °C in He flow to prevent CO from adsorption on the CeO2 material [26], the quantitative CO was pulsed until no CO consumption could be detected. Results and discussion The properties of CZA materials The HRTEM measurement were carried out to explore the distinctions in the morphology of three materials, and the results are shown as Fig. 1 . Notably, the nanorod structure (marked by yellow arrow in Fig. 1(a1) and (a2)) was only detected in CZA1, which is inferred as Al2O3 according to previous results [27,28]. Besides, the crystal plane spacing of the nanorod structure is shown in Fig. S7, which proves that it is Al2O3 once again. So, it infers that the precipitation method will cause uneven distribution of composition in the material when using pseudo-boehmite as precursor. However, the morphology of CZA2 and CZA3 are particularly similar and it is hard to absolutely distinguish the CZ and Al2O3 nano-particles according to the result of HRTEM images. Hence, the TEM-Mapping test was used to further explore the overall dispersion of each element in three CZA materials. Although the distribution of Ce and Zr is relatively homogeneous in CZA1, as displayed in Fig. 2 (a1), (a2) and (a3), the distribution between Al and Ce-Zr is akin to “mechanical mixing” (marked with white circle area). In addition, compared with CZA2, obviously, the three elements (Ce, Zr and Al) in CZA3 are more evenly distributed. It may be caused by different ways to introduce CZ into Al2O3 with network structure, resulting in different existing states of CZ. In CZA2, Ce4+ and Zr4+ exist in the form of precipitates such as carbonates and hydroxides after being precipitated. But as for CZA3, the reactants exist in ionic state when directly disperse the precursor solution of CZ in Al2O3, so Ce4+ and Zr4+ can achieve molecular level uniformity in a very short time and it is easy to obtain samples with more consistent component distribution compared with precipitation method [23]. In conclusion, the elements in the CZA material that obtained by peptization are more evenly distributed, which is conducive to inhibiting the sintering of CZ and enhance the interaction between the noble metals and support. Besides, whether the CZ-rich structure is obtained can be judged by the element distribution of the material. Hence, the XPS was tested to inquiry the surface element composition. Fig. 3 (a) are the results of Ce/Al ratio and Ce/Zr ratio of CZA samples, which are calculated from the normalized peak areas of Ce 3d, Zr 3d, Al 2p XPS spectra (Fig. S1). Notably, the Ce/Al ratio of both CZA1 and CZA2 are 0.05. However, the one in CZA3 reaches up to 0.12, which indicates there are more Ce element on the surface of Al2O3, namely, the relative CZ-rich surface are obtained in CZA3. It's rational to infer the Pd-only TWCs based on CZA3 possess better catalytic active due to that CZ has stronger anchoring effect on Pd than Al2O3 [15]. Besides, compared with CZA2 (0.65) and CZA3 (0.63), the Ce/Zr ratio value of CZA3 (1.24) is much higher and even exceeds theoretical Ce/Zr ratio of 1.00. It manifests that formation of Ce-rich surface in CZ solution of CZA3. Fig. 3(b) displays the O 1 s XPS spectra of CZA materials. As reported in literatures, it could be split into Oα (lattice oxygen), Oβ (defect oxides) and Oγ (surface chemisorbed oxygen species), respectively [29]. Generally, the Oα peak on the lower binding energy side of the O 1 s spectrum is attributed to O2− ions surrounded by Ce4+ ions, which corresponds to the Ce-O bond in CeO2. The Oβ peak can be ascribed to the O2− ions in the Ce-O bond where Ce is present in the +3 state [48]. Thus, the increase in Oβ/O ratio of material implies the increase in surface oxygen vacancies. In general, the existence of oxygen vacancy could improve the mobility of oxygen species and plays a significant key role in redox properties [30]. The Oβ value is gradually increasing as following: CZA1 (54.05%) ˂ CZA2 (58.82%) ˂ CZA3 (60.98%). Consequently, the CZA3 possesses more surface oxygen vacancies, which may improve its reducibility to some extent. Besides, oxygen vacancies are beneficial for anchoring noble metals, resulting in inhibiting their accumulation, improving their dispersion, enhancing the interaction between noble metals and supports, and ultimately promoting the elimination of HC and CO [43]. The XRD measurement was used to further investigate structure of CZA samples. The structures of γ-Al2O3 (PDF 75–0921) and Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 (PDF 38–1436) were tested in CZA materials, as depicted in Fig.4 (a), manifesting the existence of CZ solid solution [31]. However, except the characteristic peaks of Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 were detected, some peaks of Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (PDF 28–0271) also existed in CZA3. Considering the theoretical value of Ce/Zr in CZA material should be 1/1, so, in addition to the CZ phase of Ce-rich was detected by XRD, there also was some CZ species of Zr-rich in this sample. As reported in literature [32], the CZ of Zr-rich can stabilize Al2O3 more effectively than CZ phase of Ce-rich, it can be inferred that the existence of Al2O3 destroys the homogeneity of CZ solid solution. And some CZ species of Zr-rich are closely contacted with Al2O3 since the effect of ZrO2 and Al2O3 is stronger than that of CeO2 and Al2O3, which exist in an amorphous shape and cannot be detected by XRD. Besides, peak intensity of CZA3 is obviously weaker than that of CZA1 and CZA2, suggesting it possesses smaller grain size, which can be observed in Fig. S8 [33]. Contacting with TEM-Mapping result, it may benefit from the uniform distribution of components in CZA3, which inhibits the sintering of CZ particles. Besides, the N2 adsorption-desorption isothermals were measured to explore the texture properties of samples, the results are drawn as Fig. 4(b) and Fig. S2. Among that, specific surface area from CZA1 to CZA3 are 60.4, 72.5 and 54.3 m2/g, respectively. It suggests the precipitation-peptization method greatly enhances texture performance and the obtained material possesses larger specific surface area. In addition to structure and texture properties, the reductive performance of CZA is also vital for catalytic performance. The Fig. 4(c) is the result of H2-TPR measurement. Obviously, the reduction peaks of CZA materials are asymmetric, indicating the existence of reducing species in different chemical environments [34]. It may be attributed to the uneven phase composition or particle size of CZ in each sample [49,50]. Besides, for CZA2, the reduction temperature (576 °C) is lower than others, which probably benefit from its higher specific surface area. Notably, the illustration on the right of Fig. 4(c) is an enlarged part of the H2-TPR profile in the range of 450⁓550 °C, in which CZA3 shows a low-temperature shoulder, demonstrating the mobility of oxygen species is faster. Additionally, as Fig. 4(d), the initial H2 consumption rate was calculated in order to further explore the low temperature redox properties of samples. It is pretty apparent that increased by sequence of CZA3 > CZA2 > CZA1. Hence, CZA3 possesses a greater H2 consumption rate below 550 °C although the reduction temperature of CZA2 is lower, suggesting more mobile oxygen species in CZA3 again [34,35]. Considering the fact that the specific surface area of CZA3 is lower, its outstanding low temperature reducing performance may relate to the CZ-rich surface of CZA3 based on the above results. According to literatures [36], for CeO2-based materials, the CZ-rich surface is beneficial to interact with H2 to produce more surface oxygen vacancies, resulting in accelerating the movement of bulk oxygen to the surface and increasing the overall defect structure. So, compared with others, the CZA3 exhibits the best low temperature reducing performance. Combined with the structure of Al2O3 prepared by peptization reported in the literatures and the results of HRTEM and TEM-Mapping, it can be inferred that the final spatial structure of Al2O3 may be similar to an amorphous network structure. And when precursor solution of CZ was directly introduced into Al2O3 prepared by peptization, it could transform into CZ oxide anchored in the framework of Al2O3 by in-situ growth in the calcitonin process. Hence, the obtained CZA3 material possess a relative CZ-rich surface and dispersed CZ nanoparticles, which facilitates to improving the low temperature redox properties and inhibiting sintering of CZ particles. Based on the above discussion, the structure diagram of CZA material was drawn as Fig. 5 . In short, the amorphous network structure can be obtained by peptizing Al2O3, which benefits to disperse CZ. Moreover, on the basis of peptizing Al2O3, compared with precipitated CZ, dispersing the precursor solution of CZ in Al2O3 directly is more conducive to dispersing CZ particle and forming relative CZ-rich surface on Al2O3. And in order to further study the relationship between the properties of CZA materials obtained by different preparation method and the three-way catalytic activity of corresponding Pd/CZA catalyst, the following characterizations were carried out. The properties of Pd/CZA catalysts H2-TPR results The reduction performance of catalyst significantly affects its three-way activity. Hence, H2-TPR test of Pd/CZA catalysts was carried out. As Fig. 6 , all catalysts present a negative peak at low temperature own to the decomposition of PdHx species. In general, H2 could be adsorbed by Pd0 and translated into PdHx species at room temperature. The PdHx species are easy to decompose with the increase of test temperature, resulting in a negative peak shown in H2-TPR [15]. Moreover, the reduction peak of all catalysts below 200 °C and display an asymmetric shape. It is the overlay of the reduction of stable PdO species that has a strong interaction with the support and the reduction of Ce4+ that has a strong interaction with PdO species through hydrogen spillover from Pd to CZA [15,37]. In general, the reduction temperature of stable PdO is lower, it suggests an easier reducibility of PdO on support and likely the presence of more dispersed PdOx on the surface, which is helpful to the catalytic performance [38]. And the reduction temperature of Ce4+ that has a strong interaction with PdO species is one of characterizations about the degree of interaction between Pd and CZA support. Namely, the spillover phenomenon of adsorption hydrogen from Pd particles to CZA is more likely to occur due to stronger interaction between Pd and CZA, as a result, the reduction of interfacial Ce4+ happened at lower temperature [39,40]. And stronger Pd-CZA interaction is beneficial to stabilize the noble metal Pd at a higher valence or smaller particle size, resulting in a superior three-way catalytic activity. Contacting to Fig. 6, in fresh samples, an obvious low-temperature reduction shoulder peak appears at 60 °C in Pd/CZA3-f, which indicates better reduction behavior in Pd/CZA3-f, which may be due to the favorable low-temperature redox performance of CZA3 support. After aging, the increased reduction temperature peak in all samples were observed on account of agglomerate of PdO particles. In detail, they decreased in the order of Pd/CZA1-a (126 °C) > Pd/CZA2-a (105 °C) > Pd/CZA3-a (103 °C), indicating Pd-CZA interaction gradually increases from Pd/CZA1-a to Pd/CZA3-a, which may benefit from the CZ-rich surface and dispersed CZ nanoparticles of CZA3 support. Besides, there is still a low temperature reduction shoulder peak in Pd/CZA2-a and Pd/CZA3-a, especially in Pd/CZA3-a, whose reduction temperature is only 64 °C. And all the reduction species of Pd/CZA3-a can be reduced at a lower temperature, which manifests the outstanding reduction performance in Pd/CZA3-a. The stronger metal-support interaction and better reduction behavior in Pd/CZA3-a may facilitate enhancing the three-way catalytic activity [38,41]. XPS results (In formula b, SPd is the average particle diameter of Pd (nm), M is the atomic mass of Pd (g/mol), ns is the average number of atoms per unit surface area (1.26×1019 atoms/m2), ρ is the mass density of Pd (12.02 g/cm3), NA is Avogadro constant (6.022×1023 mol−1), and D is the dispersion of Pd (%)) Moreover, the surface content and chemical state of Pd also have a favorable effect on three-way catalytic activity. So, they are calculated from the normalized peak areas of the Ce 3d (Fig. S3), Al 2p (Fig. S4), Zr 3d (Fig. S5), O 1 s (Fig. S6) and Pd 3d (Fig. 7 ) core level spectra, and the results are listed in Table 2 , together with Pd dispersion and particle size calculated according to CO chemisorption. As depicted in Table 2, both ratios of Ce/Al and Ce/Zr decline evidently in Pd/CZA3 when Pd is loaded on the CZA material. It infers that more Pd species may preferentially adsorb on the surface Ce sites by forming Pd-O-Ce bonds to better disperse Pd, which leads to the reduction of Ce content on the surface [42]. And, the surface content and dispersion of Pd in Pd/CZA3-f reach up to 0.75% and 25%, respectively. They are pretty higher than others and it may benefit from CZ-rich surface and dispersed CZ nanoparticles of CZA3 support as mentioned above [43]. Moreover, the changes of binding energy of Pd 3d between Pd/CZA catalysts were presented as Fig. 7. Notably, the increased binding energies of Pd 3d as Pd/CZA1-f (336.5 eV) ˂ Pd/CZA2-f (336.6 eV) ˂ Pd/CZA3-f (336.7 eV). On the one hand, the shift of binding energy towards the high-energy end in Pd 3d XPS spectra can be explained by the electron transfer between Pd2+ and Ce4+, suggesting the interaction between metal and support enhances [44]. On the other hand, according to the research of Kobayshi [45], the higher binding energy of Pd 3d orbitals may also be related to the smaller Pd particles. Contacting with the result with CO chemisorption, it can be observed the Pd particle size of three fresh Pd/CZA catalysts are pretty similar. Therefore, the higher Pd 3d orbital binding energy in Pd/CZA3-f can be attributed to the stronger interaction between Pd and CZA3. On account of sintering and decomposition of noble metal Pd in thermal aging treatment process, the surface content of Pd and Pd2+/Pd value decreased in aged catalysts. Nevertheless, Pd/CZA3-a still maintains the highest contents, which are 0.68% and 77.78%, respectively, meaning there are plentiful three-way catalytic sites. And the difference in binding energies and dispersion of Pd is more obvious, whose sequence is CZA3-a (336.8 eV, 13%) ˃ CZA2-a (336.7 eV, 6%) ˃ CZA1-a (336.6 eV, 4%). Compared with others, the Pd particle size of Pd/CZA3-a (8.5 nm) is also smaller, manifesting the sintering of palladium grains is inhibited. Taking into account the fact that CZA3 support possesses a smaller specific surface area, the reason for more active sites in both fresh and aged Pd/CZA3 probably own to the relative CZ-rich surface and dispersed CZ nanoparticles of CZA3 support. HRTEM results From above results, it is found that the distinctions of properties between aged catalysts becomes more obvious. Among that, the Pd/CZA3-a catalyst possesses more active sites. In order to further obtain more information about morphology and structure of aged one, the HRTEM measurement was carried out. As illustrated in Fig. 8 . the characteristic d -spacing of CZ, Al2O3 and PdO were detected in all aged catalysts. Notably, compared with Pd/CZA1-a and Pd/CZA2-a, more obvious interfaces of Pd-CZ are observed in Pd/CZA3-a (marked by red ‘interface’), which is expected to increase more PdO species, resulting in a favorable influence on the catalytic performance [14,46]. Three-way catalytic activity results The activity result of catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 9 . Among the fresh one, Pd/CZA3-f shows more excellent conversion performance for all pollutants due to lower T 50 (the light-off temperature at 50% conversion) and T 90 (the full conversion temperature at 90% conversion). According to results of XPS and CO-adsorption, it mainly due to stronger interaction between noble metal and support, resulting in a higher surface content (0.75%) and dispersion (25%) of Pd species. The apparent deactivation for all catalysts is found after aged at 900 °C for 3 h, it's leaded by the sintering and decomposition of Pd species. Nevertheless, the Pd/CZA3-a still remained the best three-way catalyst activity, and the details are as follows: Pd/CZA3-a ˃ Pd/CZA2-a ˃ Pd/CZA1-a. Comparing with that of Pd/CZA1-a, the T90 of CO, NO, C3H6 and C3H8 of Pd/CZA3-a was reduced by 40 °C, 50 °C, 40 °C and 20 °C, respectively. It infers there are two main reasons about that. On the one hand, the low-temperature reduction ability is one of essential indexes. Related to H2-TPR measurement, the reduction performance of three aged catalysts is in accord with the corresponding catalytic activity well; On the other hand, based on the results of XPS, CO-adsorption and TEM, the strong interaction between support and noble metal is beneficial to produce more PdO species, whose sequence also decreased as Pd/CZA3-a ˃ Pd/CZA2-a ˃ Pd/CZA1-a, resulting in promoting catalytic conversion of HC and CO [16]. Besides, as for the reaction mechanism of NO + C3H8, who are the most difficult to be converted in the three-way reaction, one of explanations includes the following three steps [14,47]: (1) * O 2 + H 2 O + * → * OOH + * OH (2) NO + * OOH + * → * N O 2 + * OH (3) 10 * N O 2 + 2 C 3 H 8 → 5 N 2 + 8 H 2 O + 6 C O 2 + * Among them, * represents the adsorption site. First, the oxidized Pd is converted to PdOOH species via proton transfer H2O on the Pd/CZA catalyst (Eq. (1)). Then, NO is adsorbed on PdOOH and oxidized to *NO2 by the O of PdOOH. Finally, C3H8 reacts with *NO2. In combination with the result that Pd/CZA3-a possesses abundant Pd2+, so, it exhibits remarkable elimination efficiency of NO and C3H8. Conclusions In this study, the CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 (CZA) materials with relative CZ-rich surface and dispersed CZ nanoparticles was prepared by peptization method. For comparison, two other CZA samples were prepared by using conventional precipitation method and peptization-precipitation method, respectively. The results show that the structure with relatively CZ-rich surface and highly dispersed CZ nanoparticles on Al2O3 is extremely important to enhance the interaction between Pd and CZA. It favors keeping the noble metal Pd at a higher valence and smaller particle size, resulting in a superior three-way catalytic activity. Comparing with the T90 of CO, NO, C3H6 and C3H8 of Pd/CZA derived from conventional precipitation method, the one of Pd/CZA catalyst from peptization method was reduced by 40 °C, 50 °C, 40 °C and 20 °C even being thermal aged at 900 ℃/3 h, respectively. In conclusion, this research findings present precious approach about the design of outstanding catalyst for the suppression of vehicle exhaust emissions. coredata.dc:description: The sintering of Pd under high temperature operation conditions usually leads to serious deactivation of Pd-based TWCs. As the stronger Pd-CeO2-ZrO2(Pd-CZ) interaction in the form of Pd-O-Ce bond favors to anchor Pd species than that of Pd-Al2O3, to construct a CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3(CZA) support with a relative CZ-rich surface is beneficial to selectively enlarger the Pd-CZ interface to maintain the excellent catalytic function of Pd/CZA TWCs. For the purpose, a facile one step peptizing method has been put forward to achieve the CZA material to stabilize Pd species. By XRD, TEM and Mapping, it could be inferred that comparing with the conventional precipitation method and peptization-precipitation method, the CZ nanoparticles could be homogeneously distributed on the network structure of porous Al2O3 by in-situ growth in the peptization method. Then the CZA with a relative CZ-rich surface could be obtained, which interacted strongly with the supported Pd species and thus stabilized the Pd species in oxidation states and smaller particle size. As a result, the Pd/CZA catalyst from peptization method exhibited the best activity for CO, NO, C3H6 and C3H8, the T90 (complete conversion temperature at 90% conversion) of which was reduced by 40 °C, 50 °C, 40 °C and 20 °C comparing with that of Pd/CZA derived from conventional precipitation method even being thermal aged at 900 ℃/3 h, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Construct CeO2-ZrO2-Al2O3 support with relative CeO2-ZrO2-rich surface by peptization method to tame the thermal stability of Pd species in three-way catalysts
